in this episode we're going to take a

and what's being done to fix it during
and after the 2016 presidential election
fears of voting machine vulnerabilities
began cropping up all over the country
investigations were mounted and in some
cases it was revealed that there were
critical security flaws in the machines
used to record ballots some people were
quick to assume foul play and while that
is certainly possible there are bigger
less dramatic problems first there's the
age of the equipment many counties have
been using the same machines for almost
two decades often running software as
outdated as Windows XP and which have
been unsupported by the manufacturer for
years so what does that mean if an
exploit is found for one of these
machines that means all of that product
line is vulnerable and will continue to
be open for attack because the machines
don't get security updates anymore to
illustrate just how susceptible these
machines are to tampering computer
scientists and academics have been
buying and hacking them one high-profile
example was the 2017 DEFCON hacking
conference where security experts
published a report showing how they had
compromised a whole suite of voting
machines and exposed absurdly poor
programming this revelation resulted in
the state of Virginia decommissioning
their voting machines and switching to
paper ballots which are in theory more
secure another big problem is the fact
that the companies who own and
manufacture these machines are privately
owned very secretive and actively tried
to prevent security experts from
analyzing their equipment they don't
offer the code to anyone for probing and
have even threatened legal action
against anyone who tries to find
weaknesses in their machines there are
no technical standards for voting
machine manufacturers and they enjoy
incredibly limited government regulation
they
basically allowing them to sell whatever
they want so to recap the voting
population depends on twenty-year-old
machines running easily exploitable
software the machines themselves don't
have to comply to any security standards
the companies refuse to work with
security experts and in some cases the
machines have even been found to be
remotely accessible despite claims to
the contrary how do we fix this the
seemingly obvious answer would be to
switch to newer machines that provide a
paper trail that is a physical copy of
all ballots that can be verified and
stored in secure lock boxes to settle
any discrepancies some states and
counties are trying their best to
upgrade their equipment before the 2020
election which is expected to be
contentious to say the least and it
would be best for everyone if the
outcome was more easily verifiable
Williamson County Tennessee for example
has just made the transition to newer
image cast voting machines with optical
scanners a significant change from the
old technology they've used since 2006
these new hybrid ballot marking devices
or BMDs
should offer another layer of
accountability within the system the
process while different from what many
voters may be used to is fairly simple
you make your selections on a
touchscreen voting machine which then
prints out a paper copy for you to look
over if everything looks accurate you
insert it into the optical scanner which
counts the ballot and stores the
physical copy in a secure lockbox
this will allow actual human election
officials to audit the election if
necessary but as with anything these new
BMDs have some problems of their own
first if a voter were to leave any races
blank the system could theoretically
autofill those fields without leaving a
trace on the printed copy creating a
discrepancy second these machines have
an option to allow the voter to submit
their ballot without reviewing it which
means the machine can send the ballot to
the printer and straight into the lock
box without the voter ever verifying
their votes were recorded accurately
this could be remedied by the
manufacturer removing that option or by
voters showing a little personal
accountability and reviewing their
ballot but that may be asking too much
1/3 much more potentially dangerous
problem is that many of these new BMDs
print a sort of two in one physical
ballot part designed to be read by
humans and part by the optical scanner
the part intended for humans is just a
list of the candidates the voter
selected but the one for the optical
scanner is a QR code this might not
sound like a big deal but consider the
fact that there's really no way for the
voter to decipher if the QR code
accurately reflects his or her vote
the list is there for the voters peace

the candidate with the most beans wins
